definition:
If for a given prime number $q$ there is no smaller prime $p$ and
nonzero integer $b$ such that $q  = 2b^2 + p$, then $q$ is a *Stern
prime*. These primes were first studied by Moritz Abraham Stern, in
connection to a lesser known conjecture of Goldbach’s. Like other
mathematicians of the time, Stern considered 1 to be a prime number.
Thus his list of Stern primes read thus: 2, 17, 137, 227, 977, 1187,
1493. A century later the list has been amended to include 3 (as in
A042978 of Sloane’s OEIS) but no terms larger than 1493 have been found.
The larger of a twin prime is not a Stern prime.
